current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text: To establish the Alyce Spotted Bear and Walter Soboleff Commission on Native Children, and for other purposes.

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the

short-title.#text: Alyce Spotted Bear and Walter Soboleff Commission on Native Children Act

text.#text:
This Act
			 may be cited as the
the United States has a distinct legal, treaty, and trust obligation to provide for the education, health care, safety, social welfare, and other needs of Native children;

chronic underfunding of Federal programs to fulfill the longstanding Federal trust obligation has resulted in limited access to critical services for the more than 2,100,000 Native children under the age of 24 living in the United States;
Native children are the most at-risk population in the United States, confronting serious disparities in education, health, and safety, with 37 percent living in poverty;

17 percent of Native children have no health insurance coverage, and child mortality has increased 15 percent among Native children aged 1 to 14, while the overall rate of child mortality in the United States decreased by 9 percent;

suicide is the second leading cause of death in Native children aged 15 through 24, a rate that is 2.5 times the national average, and violence, including intentional injuries, homicide, and suicide, account for 75 percent of the deaths of Native children aged 12 through 20;

58 percent of 3- and 4-year-old Native children are not attending any form of preschool, 15 percent of Native children are not in school and not working, and the graduation rate for Native high school students is 50 percent;
22.9 percent of Native children aged 12 and older report alcohol use, 16 percent report substance dependence or abuse, 35.8 percent report tobacco use, and 12.5 percent report illicit drug use;
Native children disproportionately enter foster care at a rate more than 2.1 times the general population and have the third highest rate of victimization; and

there is no resource that is more vital to the continued existence and integrity of Native communities than Native children, and the United States has a direct interest, as trustee, in protecting Native children.
In this Act:

text.#text: The

header.#text:
Comprehensive
			 study of Native children issues

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall conduct a
			 comprehensive study of Federal, State, local, and tribal programs that serve Native
			 children, including an evaluation of—
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Alyce Spotted Bear and Walter Soboleff Commission on Native Children

text.#text: The

the impact of
			 concurrent jurisdiction on child welfare systems;

the issues
			 relating to data collection, such as small sample sizes, large margins of
			 errors, or other issues related to the validity and statistical significance of
			 data on Native children;

the barriers to
			 the development of sustainable, multidisciplinary programs designed to assist
			 high-risk Native children and families of those high-risk Native children, as
			 well as any examples of successful program models and use of best practices; and
the barriers to interagency coordination on programs benefitting Native children.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , to avoid duplication of efforts,  the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Alyce Spotted Bear and Walter Soboleff Commission on Native Children Act/s:4/ss:e/p:1

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall, to the maximum extent practicable, collaborate with other workgroups focused on similar issues, such as the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Alyce Spotted Bear and Walter Soboleff Commission on Native Children

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Task Force on American Indian/Alaska Native Children Exposed to Violence
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Task Force on American Indian-Alaskan Native Children Exposed to Violence

text.#text: In conducting the study under

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
and the
			 analysis of any existing data relating to Native children received from Federal
			 agencies, the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Alyce Spotted Bear and Walter Soboleff Commission on Native Children Act/s:4/ss:e/p:1
Alyce Spotted Bear and Walter Soboleff Commission on Native Children

text.#text:
Taking
			 into consideration the results of the study under

develop goals, and plans for achieving those goals, for
			 Federal policy relating to Native children in the short-, mid-, and long-term,
			 which shall be informed by the development of accurate child well-being
			 measures;

make
			 recommendations on necessary modifications and improvements to programs that
			 serve Native children at the Federal, State, and tribal level that integrate
			 the cultural strengths of the communities of the Native children and will
			 result in—

improvements to
			 the child welfare system that—

increase
			 coordination among social workers, police, and foster families assisting Native
			 children while in the foster system to result in the increased safety of Native
			 children while in the foster system;

encourage the
			 hiring and retention of licensed social workers in Native communities;

address the lack
			 of available foster homes in Native communities; and
improve the academic proficiency and graduation rates of Native children in the foster system;

improvements to
			 the mental and physical health of Native children, taking into consideration
			 the rates of suicide, substance abuse, and access to nutrition and health care,
			 including—

an analysis of the increased access of Native children to Medicaid
			 under the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
and
			 the effect of that increase on the ability of Indian tribes and Native Hawaiians to develop
			 sustainable health programs; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act
public-law/111/148

text.#text: an evaluation of the effects of a lack of public sanitation infrastructure, including in-home sewer and water, on the health status of Native children;

improvements to
			 educational and vocational opportunities for Native children that will lead to—
scholarship opportunities at a Tribal College or University and other public and private postsecondary institutions;
increased participation of the immediate families of Native children;
coordination among schools and Indian tribes that serve Native children, including in the areas of data sharing and student tracking;
accurate identification of students as Native children; and
increased school counseling services, improved access to quality nutrition at school, and safe student transportation;
improved policies and practices by local school districts that would result in improved academic proficiency  for Native children;

increased access
			 to extracurricular activities for Native children that are designed to increase
			 self-esteem,  promote community engagement, and support academic excellence  while also serving to prevent
			 unplanned pregnancy, membership in gangs, drug and alcohol abuse, and suicide,
			 including activities that incorporate traditional language and cultural
			 practices of Indians and Native Hawaiians;

improvements to
			 Federal, State, and tribal juvenile detention programs—

to incorporate
			 families and the traditional cultures of Indians and Native Hawaiians in the
			 process, including through the development of a family court for juvenile
			 offenses; and
to prevent unnecessary detentions and identify successful reentry programs;

expanded access to a continuum of early development and learning services for Native children from prenatal to age 5 that are culturally competent, support Native language preservation, and comprehensively promote the health, well-being, learning, and development of Native children, such as—
high quality early care and learning programs for children starting from birth, including Early Head Start, Head Start, child care, and preschool programs;

programs, including home visiting and family resource and support programs, that increase the capacity of parents to support the learning and development of the children of the parents, beginning prenatally, and connect the parents with necessary resources;
early intervention and preschool services for infants, toddlers, and preschool-aged children with developmental delays or disabilities; and
professional development opportunities for Native providers of early development and learning services;

the development
			 of a system that delivers wrap-around services to Native children in a way that is comprehensive and sustainable, including through increased coordination among Indian tribes, schools, law enforcement, health care providers, social workers, and families;

more flexible use
			 of existing Federal programs, such as by—

providing Indians and Native Hawaiians with more
			 flexibility to carry out programs, while minimizing administrative time, cost,
			 and expense and reducing the burden of Federal paperwork requirements; and

allowing unexpended Federal funds to be used flexibly across Federal agencies
			 to support programs benefitting Native children, while taking into account—

the 477
			 Demonstration Initiative of the

the Coordinated
			 Tribal Assistance Solicitation program of the

the Federal
			 policy of self-determination; and

any consolidated
			 grant programs; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, would improve the health,
			 safety, and well-being of Native children;
